headline.main: A Well-Deserved Defeat for the Religious Right

docs.abstract: The Senate narrowly defeated the Blunt amendment, which would have allowed any employer to deny insurance coverage for religious or moral reasons.
docs.snippet: The Senate narrowly defeated the Blunt amendment, which would have allowed any employer to deny insurance coverage for religious or moral reasons.

headline.main: Behind the Screen at Cuomo's Online Chat
headline.print_headline: The Governor Will Now Take Questions. Except That One, or That One ...

docs.abstract: Inquiries about hydrofracking and health benefits for laid-off workers were among the hundreds of questions that Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo did not answer in his first online chat.
docs.snippet: Inquiries about hydrofracking and health benefits for laid-off workers were among the hundreds of questions that Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo did not answer in his first online chat.

docs.abstract: George Packer's selective defense of religious liberty.
docs.snippet: George Packer's selective defense of religious liberty.

headline.main: Boehner Vows to Continue Contraception Fight

docs.abstract: The battle over whether to allow employers to opt out of contraception coverage may be over in the Senate, but House Speaker John A. Boehner signaled Thursday that House Republicans will continue the fight.
docs.snippet: The battle over whether to allow employers to opt out of contraception coverage may be over in the Senate, but House Speaker John A. Boehner signaled Thursday that House Republicans will continue the fight.

headline.main: A Criminal Virus Born of Russia and the Soviet Past Spreads

docs.abstract: A sprawling conspiracy to scam insurance companies in New York is traced to the city's Russian-speaking immigrant community, raising uncomfortable questions.
docs.snippet: A sprawling conspiracy to scam insurance companies in New York is traced to the city's Russian-speaking immigrant community, raising uncomfortable questions.

docs.lead_paragraph: The criminal case against the financier R. Allen Stanford was handed over to a jury in Houston after the prosecution and the defense finished their closing arguments in the fraud trial.

headline.seo: The Stanford Fraud Case Goes to Jury
headline.main: With Closing Statements Made, Financier’s Fraud Case Goes to Jury
headline.print_headline: With Closing Statements Made, Financier’s Fraud Case Goes to Jury

docs.abstract: Criminal case against financier R Allen Stanford is handed over to a jury in Houston after the prosecution and the defense finish their closing arguments; if convicted, he could be sentenced to more than 20 years in prison for masterminding a $7 billion Ponzi scheme.
docs.snippet: The criminal case against the financier R. Allen Stanford was handed over to a jury in Houston after the prosecution and the defense finished their closing arguments in the fraud trial.

docs.lead_paragraph: The president-elect of the American Medical Association responds to an editorial.

headline.seo: From the A.M.A.: Medicare Doctor Payments

docs.abstract: Letter from American Medical Association President-elect Jeremy Lazarus responds to Feb 22 editorial on fees paid to doctors by Medicare.
docs.snippet: The president-elect of the American Medical Association responds to an editorial.

docs.lead_paragraph: Mitt Romney may have won in Michigan, but the out-of-touch Republican campaigns ignore the problems of blue-collar voters.

headline.seo: Romney Wins and the Middle Class Loses
headline.main: Romney Wins, the Middle Class Loses
headline.print_headline: Romney Wins, the Middle Class Loses

docs.abstract: Editorial contends that acrimonious battle between Rick Santorum and Mitt Romney over the Michigan primary may have cost the Republican party that state in the general election; holds that both candidates ran campaigns that were completely disconnected from the lives of middle-class voters; notes that Pres Obama capitalized on this disconnect during fiery speech to the United Auto Workers.
docs.snippet: Mitt Romney may have won in Michigan, but the out-of-touch Republican campaigns ignore the problems of blue-collar voters.

docs.lead_paragraph: With the unemployment rate still high, colleges are tailoring their continuing-education programs to suit current and future job openings.

headline.seo: Schools Try to Match the Jobless With 3.4 Million Jobs
headline.main: Schools Try to Match the Jobless With 3.4 Million Jobs

docs.abstract: Colleges are tailoring their continuing education programs to help unemployed workers; are gearing their curriculum toward jobs that are in demand now and will be in the future.
docs.snippet: With the unemployment rate still high, colleges are tailoring their continuing-education programs to suit current and future job openings.

docs.lead_paragraph: An organized crime ring conspired to steal more than $250 million, federal authorities said.

headline.seo: Dozens Said to Be Arrested in Health Care Fraud Scheme
headline.main: A $250 Million Fraud Scheme Finds a Path to Brighton Beach
headline.print_headline: A $250 Million Fraud Scheme Finds a Path to Brighton Beach

docs.abstract: Federal authorities say an crime ring in Brighton Beach, Brooklyn, conspired to steal more than $250 million from health insurance companies; details cast unflattering spotlight on how Russian-speaking immigrants have often dominated such schemes in New York City; plot involved 10 doctors, 9 separate clinics and 105 different corporations.
docs.snippet: An organized crime ring conspired to steal more than $250 million, federal authorities said.

byline.contributor: Colin Moynihan and Tim Stelloh contributed reporting.
